DOCNAME: CASE OF AUTRONIC AG v. SWITZERLAND
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . Autronic AG is a limited company incorporated under NORP law and has its head office at GPE ( GPE of GPE ) . It specialises in electronics and in particular sells QUANTITY - diameter dish aerials for home use .

CARDINAL . ORG Its application relates to the reception in GPE of uncoded television programmes made and broadcast in GPE . They are transmitted to the NORP satellite ORG ( also called PERSON ) , which sends them back to receiving earth stations on NORP territory , and these in turn distribute them to users . The satellite is a telecommunications satellite and not a direct - broadcasting CARDINAL : it provides a fixed point - to - point radiocommunication service ( number CARDINAL of LAW - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and uses the frequencies allotted to radiocommunications . It also transmits telephone conversations , telexes or telegrams and data .
CARDINAL . ORG In DATE the only television broadcasts by satellite that could be received in GPE by means of a dish aerial were those from ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE applied to ORG of ORG of the national ORG ( PTT ) . It requested permission to give a showing at ORG ( GPE ) from CARDINAL to DATE of the public television programme that it received direct from ORG by means of a private dish aerial , its object being to give a demonstration of the technical capabilities of the equipment in order to promote sales of it .
CARDINAL . The ORG wrote to GPE embassy in GPE , which on DATE conveyed the NORP authorities’ consent for the duration of the fair .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG made a similar approach in order to give demonstrations at the ORG exhibition , which was to be held in GPE from DATE to CARDINAL DATE and covered the latest developments in radio , television and electronics .

CARDINAL . ORG again applied to the NORP embassy , but did not receive a reply . On CARDINAL and DATE and on DATE it informed ORG that without the express consent of the NORP authorities it could not allow reception of the ORG broadcasts and that ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) required it to prevent such reception .

CARDINAL . As Autronic AG was anxious to give further demonstrations , it applied to ORG , on CARDINAL DATE , for a declaratory ruling ( GPE ) that , in particular , reception for private use of uncoded television programmes from satellites such as ORG should not require the consent of the broadcasting ORG ’s authorities .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant company relied on several arguments : the confidentiality of a programme could not depend on the use of particular frequencies ; numbers DATE of ORG gave no indication of which kind of broadcast was to be kept confidential ; reception of radio and television programmes intended for and accessible to the general public could be made subject only to the award of a licence under NORP law , which was available to everybody ; and , lastly , the reception in question did not infringe NORP legislation on intellectual property , because while programmes taken individually could have the status of " works " , the same was not true of a whole schedule .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG rejected the applicant company ’s application , stating that it could not grant a receiving licence without the consent of the broadcasting ORG ’s authorities .

CARDINAL . ORG The ORG noted that only duly approved earth stations were entitled to receive signals from telecommunications satellites . In this connection it referred to number CARDINAL of ORG , under which each national authority could assign certain frequencies to point - to - point radiocommunications provided that the broadcasts were not intended for direct reception by the general public .

It also stressed the difference between broadcasting satellites and telecommunications satellites . The former transmitted radio and television programmes to an undefined number of receiving stations within a given area , on frequencies expressly reserved for direct reception , while the latter were covered by the secrecy of broadcasts which all member GPE were obliged to ensure under LAW and numbers DATE of ORG ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) . It added , lastly ( translation from NORP ) :

" As to whether a broadcast is intended for direct reception by the general public , the decisive factor is accordingly not the content of the radiocommunication transmitted ( a television programme , for example ) but the mode of its transmission , in other words its classification as a telecommunication . It follows that radio or television programmes transmitted via a telecommunications satellite can not be received in a country unless the telecommunications authority of the broadcasting ORG ... has given its permission to the telecommunications authority of the receiving ORG . This will ensure compliance with the provisions on the secrecy of telecommunications . There is no apparent reason why telecommunications authorities should not be able to keep certain radiocommunications secret since they are under an obligation to ensure that the provisions of ORG and of ORG are complied with . "
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE lodged an appeal ( Beschwerde ) against ORG decision but this was rejected by ORG on DATE .
ORG began by holding that it had jurisdiction and that the company had an interest , worthy of protection , in having the disputed decision set aside under section CARDINAL of LAW .

It went on to set out its reasons for dismissing the appeal . Protection of the material information could not depend on whether the broadcasts were intended for the general public , since as a rule it was not known , at the time of transmission by telecommunications satellites , which broadcasts were intended for general use . Furthermore , LAW secured only the right to receive information from generally accessible sources , which telecommunications satellites were not . Lastly , it was irrelevant that the broadcasts were ultimately intended for general use , as the obligation to keep the transmitted data secret subsisted at the time of broadcasting .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE lodged an administrative - law appeal with ORG against the decision of ORG of the PTT . It applied to have that decision set aside and sought a judgment which would clarify the legal situation for the future ; it asked the court in particular to rule that reception for private use of uncoded broadcasts emanating from telecommunications satellites and intended for the general public should not be subject to the broadcasting ORG ’s consent .
CARDINAL . ORG In reply to a request for information made by ORG of ORG of the NORP PTT , ORG GPE said the following in a telex of DATE :

" With reference to your letter of DATE , we should like to inform you that the programmes transmitted by ‘ ORG CARDINAL’ [ ORG ] are not satellite broadcasts intended for foreign countries . The programmes are intended for NORP television viewers and are our internal affair . On the other hand , we have no technical means of preventing them from reaching other countries , particularly GPE . As regards the international use of the signal , only discussion and settlement of the problem at world level will provide a solution . "
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG put a number of questions to the parties about the factual and legal position . ORG of the PTT replied on DATE and the applicant company on DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the rapporteur informed ORG that ORG had not yet been able to consider the appeal and that the company had until DATE to submit any further observations .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG sent the GPE telecommunications authorities the following telex :

In connection with the judgment of a request , we would like to know on which conditions reception of TV programmes via telecommunications satellites is permitted in the GPE . Please let us also know if the NORP communications satellite ORG is received in your country ( by cable operators ) .
The GPE authorities replied on DATE as follows :
" ... The conditions for reception of TV programmes by cable operators in the GPE seem to be quite similar to those in your country .

The GPE PTT issues licences to cable operators , separate for each particular TV program . With such a licence the operator can install his own TVRO antenna , although it is advisable for him to consult with PTT for frequency co - ordination purposes in order to avoid interference from terrestrial microwaves .
DATE some reception of the ORG satellite did indeed take place .
This was considered illegal because of the absence of agreements with the GPE program provider and satellite operator , and the cable operators were so informed .
In response to a similar request for information , the NORP telecommunications authorities stated the following on DATE :
We have permission from ORG of GPE to receive as an experiment the [ ORG ] signal up to CARDINAL . Authorization for distribution has been given in CARDINAL cases so far . "
CARDINAL . ORG gave judgment on DATE and served the text on ORG on DATE .

The court held that the appellant company was seeking a review in the abstract of the legal position , whereas in reality it could only complain of the ban on receiving the disputed broadcasts during the PERSON exhibition . There was , however , no point in ruling on the admissibility of the appeal , since at all events the company had failed to show that it had an interest worthy of protection .

Apart from ORG , there was no other satellite over LOC at the time whose broadcasts were receivable by means of a domestic dish aerial . ORG picked up the signals from the NORP satellite because there was no alternative source . As long as this situation continued , there would be practically no market for such equipment and only " eccentrics " ( GPE ) would be inclined to buy it . Although CARDINAL other satellites - CARDINAL NORP and CARDINAL NORP - were to be launched , it remained unclear how they would be used and it was impossible to assess either the interest that direct reception of their broadcasts would arouse or the number of dish aerials that would come into use .

ORG concluded that as it had failed to adduce evidence of any direct economic interest , the applicant company had no interest worthy of protection . It therefore refused to determine the merits of the case .

CARDINAL . ORG At the present time , there are still only a handful of direct - broadcasting satellites , whereas there are CARDINAL telecommunications satellites such as ORG , covering all or part of western LOC and broadcasting all kinds of uncoded programmes intended for the general public .
CARDINAL . ORG Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW guarantees " inviolability of the secrecy of letters and telegrams " .
CARDINAL . ORG The relevant provisions of LAW of DATE regulating telegraph and telephone communications are as follows :
" ORG shall have the exclusive right to set up and operate transmitting and receiving equipment or equipment of any kind for the electric or radio transmission of signals , images or sounds . "
" The competent authority shall be able to issue licences for setting up and operating equipment for the electric and radio transmission of signals , images and sounds . "
" The provisions required for the implementation of this Act shall be incorporated into the Ordinance on telegraphs and telephones to be enacted by ORG and in the detailed regulations ... "
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG enacted Ordinance no . CARDINAL relating to LAW ; among other things the ORG laid down the scope of television licences :

" CARDINAL . ORG I for television - receiving equipment shall entitle the holder to operate equipment for the private reception , by means of radio waves or by electric wire , of NORP and foreign public television broadcasts .
CARDINAL . Reception of television broadcasts on LOC which are not accessible to the public shall be deemed to be private .
CARDINAL . The licence - holder may himself install his equipment for receiving broadcasts by means of radio waves .

CARDINAL . A special licence must be held in order to exercise rights vested in the ORG other than those mentioned in DATE , in particular in order to demonstrate how receiving equipment works , to install receiving equipment in the homes of third parties and to arrange for public reception of broadcasts . "

CARDINAL . The revised text of Ordinance no . CARDINAL , which was enacted on CARDINAL DATE , came into force on DATE . Although it does not apply in the instant case , several of its provisions are worth quoting :
" Licences may be refused where there is good reason to suppose that the telecommunications equipment will be used for a purpose that is
( a ) unlawful ;
( b ) contrary to public morals or public policy ; or
( c ) prejudicial to the higher interests of the country , of ORG or of broadcasting . "
" Radio- and television - receiving licences shall authorise their holders to receive NORP and foreign radio broadcasts privately or publicly . "
" A community - antenna licence shall entitle the holder to :

( a ) Operate the local distribution network defined in the licence and rebroadcast by this means radio and television programmes from transmitters which comply with the provisions of LAW of DATE and ORG and with those of the international conventions and agreements concluded within ORG ;
( f ) Transmit programmes and special broadcasting services which , on the authorisation of ORG , which itself requires the ORG ’s consent , are received from telecommunications satellites ;

" The authorisation referred to in LAW ( f ) shall be granted where the appropriate telecommunications authority has given its consent and none of the grounds for refusal provided for in LAW exist . "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG submitted to ORG , by means of a communication , a draft decree of general application on satellite broadcasting . The decree , enacted on DATE and effective from CARDINAL DATE , contained an LAW concerning foreign programmes , which was worded as follows :
" CARDINAL . A licence from the [ appropriate federal ] department shall be required in order to retransmit programmes broadcast by satellite under a foreign licence .
CARDINAL . Such a licence shall be granted where this is not contrary to the country ’s higher interests and where
( a ) the PTT finds that the requirements of NORP and international telecommunications law are satisfied ;

CARDINAL . The department may refuse to grant a licence where a ORG whose licensing system allows a programme does not accept the retransmission on its territory of programmes broadcast under a NORP licence . "

CARDINAL . ORG The International Telecommunication Convention , which was concluded in DATE within ORG and has been revised several times , came into force on DATE and has been ratified by all ORG member GPE . In GPE it has been published in full in the Official Collection of Federal Statutes ( DATE , p. CARDINAL , and DATE , p. CARDINAL ) and in ORG ( CARDINAL ) .
Article CARDINAL , entitled " Secrecy of telecommunications " , provides :
" CARDINAL . Members agree to take all possible measures , compatible with the system of telecommunication used , with a view to ensuring the secrecy of international correspondence .

CARDINAL . Nevertheless , they reserve the right to communicate such correspondence to the competent authorities in order to ensure the application of their internal laws or the execution of international conventions to which they are parties . "

Under LAW member GPE are bound to abide by the Convention and the Administrative Regulations in all telecommunications offices and stations established or operated by them which engage in international services or which are capable of causing harmful interference with radio services of other countries .
CARDINAL . The Convention is complemented by CARDINAL sets of detailed administrative rules ( as indicated in DATE ) : ORG , LAW and ORG . Only LAW are relevant in the instant case .

CARDINAL . ORG date from DATE and were likewise amended in DATE and also on other occasions . They run to CARDINAL pages and - except for numbers CARDINAL and CARDINAL - have not been published in ORG . The latter contains the following reference to them :

" The administrative regulations relating to LAW of DATE are not being published in ORG . They may be consulted at ORG , ORG and ORG , Viktoriastrasse CARDINAL , ORG , or may be obtained from the ORG , ORG , ORG , GPE . "
The following provisions are the ones relevant in the present case :

" ORG : A radiocommunication service between earth stations at specified fixed points when CARDINAL or more satellites are used ; in some cases this service includes satellite - to - satellite links , which may also be effected in the inter - satellite service ; the fixed - satellite service may also include feeder links for other space radiocommunication services . "
" ORG : A radiocommunication service in which signals transmitted or retransmitted by space stations are intended for direct reception by the general public .
In the broadcasting - satellite service , the term ‘ direct reception’ shall encompass both individual reception and community reception . "

" Any administration may assign a frequency in a band allocated to the fixed service or allocated to the fixed - satellite service to a station authorized to transmit , unilaterally , from one specified fixed point to CARDINAL or more specified fixed points provided that such transmissions are not intended to be received directly by the general public . "
" In the application of the appropriate provisions of the ORG , administrations bind themselves to take the necessary measures to prohibit and prevent :
( a ) the unauthorized interception of radiocommunications not intended for the general use of the public ;

( b ) the divulgence of the contents , simple disclosure of the existence , publication or any use whatever , without authorization , of information of any nature whatever obtained by the interception of the radiocommunications mentioned [ in sub - paragraph ( a ) ] "
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Permanent Mission of Switzerland to the international organisations in GPE put CARDINAL questions to ORG , which replied on DATE , saying inter alia :

" CARDINAL . ORG With regard to this aspect of [ the ] practical pursuance [ of the principle of secrecy of telecommunications ] , it is ... important , indeed essential , to note also that no precise measures concerning practical ways of effectively ensuring such ‘ secrecy of ORG are prescribed by either the LAW or the ORG [ ORG ] , but that the ORG leave the choice of these practical measures to the administrations of the ORG ’s Members .

CARDINAL . ORG That is how it is necessary to understand and interpret numbers DATE and DATE of the ORG , which stipulate that it is administrations that bind themselves to take the necessary measures to prohibit and prevent : ( a ) the unauthorised interception of radiocommunications not intended for the general use of the public ( ... that also applies , of course , to number DATE of the ORG ) .

CARDINAL . ORG This means that it is for the administration of each of the Union ’s Members itself to take whatever measures it deems necessary to prohibit and prevent on its territory the unauthorised interception of the radiocommunications referred to in number DATE of the ORG . This , incidentally , is in accordance with the first principle laid down in the preamble to the LAW , which is worded as follows : " While fully recognising the sovereign right of each country to regulate its telecommunication ... " . In the case under consideration here ... , it is for ORG to put into effect GPE ’s undertaking to ensure the secrecy of telecommunications by whatever measures it itself considers necessary for the purpose . Such measures may , of course , be different from those regarded as necessary by the administrations of other Members of the ORG which have given the same undertaking .

CARDINAL . ORG With regard , lastly , to the authorisation required for the interception of radiocommunications not intended for the general use of the public ... , it should be inferred from the terms of numbers DATE and DATE of the ORG that an administration which has committed itself to taking the necessary measures to prohibit and prevent such unauthorised interception in order to ensure the secrecy of telecommunications is also to be regarded as the CARDINAL empowered to give , where appropriate , the authorisation for such interception on its territory and hence to lay down the terms and conditions on which it grants such authorisation . In the case under consideration here ... it is therefore ORG that , with a view to ensuring the secrecy of telecommunications , should decide whether or not such authorisation is to be granted and lay down the terms and conditions it itself considers necessary for the purposes of that decision . By way of a conclusion and a final legal consequence , it should be borne in mind that what was stated in the preceding paragraph also applies , mutatis mutandis , in respect of the authorisation itself . "
